results.title: Lewis Carroll country
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “The Last governor”.
The Sino-British talks collapse. In Hong Kong, support for Patten and his democratic reforms is undiminished despite an onslaught from the dissenters. With the help of Baroness Thatcher and other key players, this episode explores Patten’s inheritance; the 1984 Joint Declaration, under which Britain and China agreed terms for the handover of Hong Kong. Patten introduces his Reform Bill to the Legislative Council, the vote is make or break for him.

results.title: Restraint in difficult situations
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “The Last governor”.
Patten returns from China to find himself facing an array of public and private dissenters; Hong Kong tycoons, British sinologists, and senior politicians who argue that the relationship with China is more important than democracy. Patten decides to internationalise the issue and after much tortuous effort, the Chinese agree to negotiate.

results.title: A Democratic time-bomb
results.creator_credit: Francis Gerard, BBC, Dimbleby Partners and Totem Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “The Last governor”.
Written and presented by Jonathan Dimbleby, episode one begins in 1992 as Conservative MP Chris Patten leaves for Hong Kong. He was the first politician and non diplomat to be elected governor, and he was the last governor of Hong Kong before the country was handed back to China. This episode looks at the business and democratic culture of Hong Kong, the influence of colonisation on culture, the role of the media in Patten’s term, an historical overview of Asia-British relations, and the migration of Chinese peoples to Hong Kong and their present status in Hong Kong society. The episode concludes with Patten having met with Chinese delegates to discuss the terms and conditions of democratic reform.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Francis Gerard, BBC, Dimbleby Partners and Totem Productions

results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Algebra, you can do it”.
This program introduces the opposite concept of other programs in the “Algebra, you can do it” series and teaches students how to find the equation if something is known about the graph through a step by step exercises. Suitable for lower to middle secondary level students. A guide accompanies this video.

results.title: Graphing linear equations
results.creator_credit: Carla Cody Weaver, Bill Hanlon and KLVX (Television station : Las Vegas, Nev.)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Algebra, you can do it”.
This program shows how to graph a linear equation by finding the value for x and y. It also familiarises students with the correct vocabulary to use when describing linear equations. Suitable for lower to middle secondary level students. A guide accompanies this video.

results.creator_credit: Mark M Williams, Bill Hanlon and KLVX (Television station : Las Vegas, Nev.)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Algebra, you can do it”.
This program shows how to write word problems with two variables in a mathematical way and how then to solve these equations by linear combination or substitution. Suitable for lower to middle secondary level students. A guide accompanies this video.

results.title: Solving linear equations with one variable
results.creator_credit: Mark M Williams, Bill Hanlon and KLVX (Television station : Las Vegas, Nev.)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Algebra, you can do it”.
This program introduces solving linear equations with one variable when the variable is a natural number. Students will be shown basic rules that will allow them to solve this type of equation. Suitable for lower to middle secondary level students. A guide accompanies this video.

results.title: Coordinate graphing 2
results.creator_credit: Milan Herzog and Associates and ACCESS
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Mathematics for modern living”.
This episode from the “Mathematics for modern living” series teaches the basics of graphing including the slope of the line, oblique, horizontal and vertical, then progresses onto graphing linear equations (slope intercept method), two firstdegree linear equations and graphing linear inequations. Suitable for lower to middle secondary level students. A study guide accompanies this tape.
